metadata.title: Understanding Quantum ML using TensorFlow Quantum | by Meet Gandhi | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Understanding Quantum ML using TensorFlow Quantum
metadata.description: The focus of this article is to introduce the areas where combining machine learning and quantum computing is beneficial for solving a domain-specific problem.

all_paragraphs: The article is intended for beginners in quantum machine learning, the inevitable future of current classical machine learning ideas. The focus of this article is to introduce the areas where combining machine learning and quantum computing is beneficial for solving a domain-specific problem. The article is structured in a way that first the quantum computing concept related to the problem is described after which the solution to the problem by the Google AI Quantum team is delineated. Moreover, it follows the recent work published by the Google AI Quantum team in collaboration with the University of Waterloo, Alphabet’s X, and Volkswagen with regards to quantum machine learning using Tensorflow Quantum.

Before jumping into some of the problems, it is incumbent to introduce Tensorflow Quantum which is an open-source library for performing computations on quantum data as well as creating hybrid quantum-classical learning models. The white paper related to the Tensorflow Quantum library can be accessed for more technical details.

Quantum circuits necessary for quantum computation are defined as a model in which a computation is a sequence of quantum gates. TensorFlow Quantum uses Cirq for designing the logic of these quantum circuits. Before moving forward, I would encourage you to skim-through the APIs for TensorFlow Quantum and Cirq or keep the sites bookmarked for later reference as an when needed for comprehension.

For this task, we design a hybrid quantum-classical neural network for classifying between quantum data sources. The quantum data is generated from the Bloch sphere. In the Bloch sphere, we first select two rays in the XZ plane and then choose points randomly distributed around the rays. Hence the task is to separate the two blobs produced as a result of choosing the above rays. Below are the images corresponding to two different angles: θ and ϕ. Both these angles lie in the XZ plane and are measured with respect to the positive X-axis. In the images exhibited below, θ corresponds to the angle made by the blue ray with positive X-axis in XZ plane whereas ϕ in a similar way corresponds to the orange ray.
Conclusively, we can make any quantum state by using X rotation & Z rotation in the Bloch sphere.
A hybrid quantum-classical neural network model was designed for the above classification task. A schematic of a typical hybrid quantum-classical neural network is shown below.

First, a quantum data is generated which in our case are points on the surface of the Bloch sphere, thereafter a quantum circuit is created using Cirq’s quantum gates Û with Φ as their respective parameters, after which a layer from Tensorflow Quantum library is selected to perform computation on qubits in the quantum model itself. Once the quantum computation is done, the expectation of the layer output is obtained by sampling or measuring the average of the values obtained from qubits. This act of measuring removes the quantum nature of qubits resulting in a classical variable. This classical variable is then subject to a classical neural network model, ultimately outputting the prediction probabilities. In the plot below, we present a plot of training loss of the hybrid neural network trained to classify points surrounding two rays on the surface of the Bloch sphere. A decline of classification error during the ongoing training and the eventual final loss of 0.00085 at the end of training suggests that the proposed hybrid neural network was successful in classifying quantum data.

In this section, we aim to learn the dynamics of the target Hamiltonian of a given Ising model using QGRNN. A transverse-field Ising model to be employed here is a quantum rendition of the classical Ising model used in thermodynamics and magnetism. The target Hamiltonian of the Ising model is as follows:

Ising model in quantum computing is basically a grid-lattice structure with spins of the qubits represented by Z as shown in the above figure. J is a coupling coefficient signifying the strength of interactions between spin pairs of qubits whereas B is the bias coefficient for a qubit to possess a particular spin. The term X is added to convey the relative effect of any external fields to a specific qubit with respect to the nearest neighbour spin pair interactions primary to the Ising model. The interaction between spins in addition to the variable coupling strengths of the Ising model is beneficial in simulating several machine learning models like Hopfield networks and Boltzmann machines (Schuld & Petruccione (2018)). Moreover, the Ising model closely emulates the fundamental mathematics of a subclass of computational problems called Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) problems.
Having introduced the Ising model and its Hamiltonian, we present below the steps to achieve the aforementioned objective of assimilating the Ising model dynamics.

Now, we will construct a Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) to find a low energy state near to the ground state so that it can be used as the initial state of Ising model & QGRNN. The Variational method provides a way to find approximated ground energy states. Below are the low energy states obtained by training VQE as well as the training loss plot of the same.

We need to take exponentials of Hamiltonians to construct the Ising model. However, generally, the exponentiation of two non-commutable observables is not equal to the exponentiation of their sum. To solve this problem, we choose Suzuki-Trotter expansion as it leads to approximated solutions which can be calculated easily.
Now we need to initialize a QGRNN model. As the targeted Hamiltonian is not known to QGRNN, we initialized a random graph inside our QGRNN.

At this step, we have generated quantum data from the true Hamiltonian of the Ising model as well as the predicted quantum data from QGRNN. As we know, measurement on qubit results into dismantling its quantum information; hence we implement Fidelity with Swap test for comparing the true and predicted quantum states. This Swap test was utilized for calculating the average infidelity loss function to be used for training QGRNN.
Conclusively from the above exercise, we can propound that QGRNN learns time evolution dynamics of a given target Hamiltonian from its quantum data in this case resembling the Ising Model.

In this section, utilizing TensorFlow Quantum we aim to explore the combination of quantum computing and classical energy-based models. Here we will investigate the 2D Heisenberg model and apply the Variational Quantum Thermalizer (VQT) to generate the approximate thermal states of the model. VQT was introduced in the following white paper (VQT).
For tracking the performance of our energy-based learning models, we make use of a tractable quantity called Fidelity.

Based on the concept of physics and exponential families, we will be using the energy-based Boltzmann machine for learning the dynamics of the 2D Heidenberg model. The Boltzmann machine classical model can be quickly transformed into a quantum mechanical Ising model by substituting each bit with the Pauli Z operator, and mapping the spin to qubit i.e. 1 to|0⟩ and -1 to |1⟩.

When an ansatz is made with regards to zero correlations between the qubits, Boltzmann machine is reduced to a product of independent Bernoulli distributions over the set of qubits which has simplifying features. Hence we will first implement Bernoulli EBM to VQT. We use the classical VQT loss function mentioned in the VQT white paper.

Conclusively. it can be inferred from the result that Energy-based methods were successful in learning the dynamics of the Hamiltonian of the 2D Heisenberg model. Refer Restricted Boltzmann Machines (RBM) classifying MNIST for some further reading on Energy-Based Models.

After having outlined three examples as well as a comprehension regarding their Quantum Computing and Machine Learning concepts, it is imperative to not get overwhelmed. My goal of introducing Quantum Machine Learning to beginners, in addition to the application of Quantum Computing to various domain-specific problems will only be successful if you as a reader follow-through and keep updating your knowledge on Quantum Machine Learning. Below I present an interesting approach to solving combinatorial optimization problems using Quantum Machine Learning.
PennyLane: A cross-platform Python library for quantum machine learning, automatic differentiation, and optimization of hybrid quantum-classical computations.
Strawberry Fields: A full-stack Python library for designing, optimizing, and utilizing photonic quantum computers.
Graduate Student at the University of Michigan
